title: Ducking tough policy questions won't do the PM any good
text:
In September, the government announced a review into Australia’s retirement income system. "It will be very important in helping to determine future policy positions by creating a fact base of what is happening in the system,” the Treasurer said, setting the scene for a genuinely useful discussion platform. But then he ruled out having the family home included in the pension assets test.

Suggesting that equity in the family home can be accessed makes people – particularly the elderly – worry that it might be sold out from under them. And people, especially the elderly, value the security, memories and community they have built up in and around the family home.

A new political gotcha game might be to ask the government what questions it is willing to entertain.

Nobody wants people approaching the later stage of their lives feeling insecure, especially not the Coalition, which by and large gets a big chunk of these votes. But ruling the proposal out is a squib. An inquiry could be instructed to look at options that respect the sanctity of the family home. It might explore whether homeowners are open to reverse mortgages or examine the idea of the family home as an intergenerational asset that would allow equity to be released in different ways. The point is not what the exact policy suggestions should be, but the ability to consider the big picture and offer new alternatives. A hobbled inquiry can’t do that.

Now the government is doing it again. The NSW Treasurer has asked a panel of experts to consider ways in which the states could work with the Commonwealth to reform taxes and service delivery to ensure that NSW, and potentially other states that like the model, can continue to deliver the services people expect, taking into account the changing requirements and preferences of the population.

The time is now

And already the Prime Minister has ruled out any change to the GST, based on economic analysis undertaken by the government a few years ago. Previous analyses are the sort of input that inquiries, working in good faith towards the best possible solutions, should always be open to considering. A rigorous inquiry will also examine the assumptions on which the analysis was based, in case the broadened terms of reference might change the assessment.

With so many questions ruled out, a new political gotcha game might be to ask the government what questions it is willing to entertain.

If ever there’s a time for asking the hard questions, it’s in the first six months of the electoral term, when there’s plenty of time to lay out the challenges and explore acceptable compromises. A government that doesn’t trust itself to communicate with the electorate now will have a hard time explaining its failure to act come election time.

And avoiding hard questions now means finding the answers will surely get harder over time.
description: The Morrison government needs to break away from its bad habit of failing to consider reform options because of political reasons.
